item.title: My second Java
item.dc:creator: @iwasinmoparseas101cl iwasinmoparseas101class
item.description:
@iwasinmoparseas101cl wrote:

alright so I worked on it a bit and couldn’t exactly figure out how to incorporate Paint into JFrame but here was my shot at it:

import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.*;
import javax.swing.*;

public class egetJFrame extends JFrame implements ActionListener{

	private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
	private int a;
	private int b;
	private Graphics draw;
	private JButton blue, red, orange, green;
	
	public egetJFrame(){
		super("Paint");
		setSize(300,200);
		setLayout(new FlowLayout());
		blue = new JButton("Blue");
		blue.addActionListener(this);
		red = new JButton("Red");
		red.addActionListener(this);
		orange = new JButton("Orange");
		orange.addActionListener(this);
		green = new JButton("Green");
		green.addActionListener(this);
		add(blue);
		add(red);
		add(orange);
		add(green);
               //sets up GUI and buttons
	}
	
	public boolean mouseDown(Event e,int x, int y) 
	{
	a=x;
    b=y;
    return true;
	}
	public boolean mouseDrag(Event e,int x, int y)
	{	
		draw = getGraphics();
		draw.setColor(Color.red);
		draw.drawLine(a,b,x,y);
		
		a=x;
		b=y;
		return true;
	}
	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		String command = e.getActionCommand();
		if(command.equals("Blue")){
			draw.setColor(Color.BLUE);
		}
		else if(command.equals("Red")){
			draw.setColor(Color.RED);
		}
		else if(command.equals("Green")){
			draw.setColor(Color.GREEN);
		}
		else{
			draw.setColor(Color.ORANGE);
		}
		//changes colors
	}
	public static void main(String[] args){
		egetJFrame fr = new egetJFrame();
		fr.setVisible(true);
                //to run program
	}
}

now with this code you’d need to figure out a way to use Paint in the constructor. I don’t know if there is a JPaintArea like a JTextArea, I’ll leave that for you to discover.

If you are still trying to use “extend Applet” then here’s what you could do:

  1. If the mouse button is lifted (aka not dragged or clicked) change colors
    -OR-
  2. use a Listener to allow hte user to just hit a key (b for blue, r for red, etc.) and do draw.setColor(userOption);

item.title: My second Java
item.dc:creator: @iwasinmoparseas101cl iwasinmoparseas101class
item.description:
@iwasinmoparseas101cl wrote:

my question to you is: why don’t you use a JFrame instead of JApplet? Also, are you using an ActionListener to see which button the user pushes?

example:

JButton blue = new JButton("Blue");
blue.addActionListener(this);
...
...
...
public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e){
     String command = e.getActionCommand();
     if(command.equals("Blue")){ //using buttons Label for command...check case-sensitivity
          draw.setColor(Color.BLUE);
     }
}

in order to use this code, you’ll have to set the Graphic draw as a private instance variable. Hope this helps! Let me know how it works for you
r
EDIT: also change your instance variables to private instead of just “int a;” it’s common practice to do this, later on you will learn about Protected and the use of Public vs. Private vs. Protected (if you don’t already know by now).

item.title: My second Java
item.dc:creator: @iwasinmoparseas101cl iwasinmoparseas101class
item.description:
@iwasinmoparseas101cl wrote:

recursion is simply calling a method over and over again through the use of Stacks.

example:

public class recursion {

	/**
	 * @param args
	 */
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		backwards(251);
	}
	public static void backwards(int num){
	      if(num < 10){
	          System.out.print(num);
	      }
	      else{
	    	  System.out.print(num%10);
	    	  backwards(num/10);
	      }
	}

}

P.S. Nice little draw applet Hope my recursion is easy to understand. just writes a number backwards: (251 to 152) etc. You could even use recursion for your java1 program and just use the str.substring(start,end) method to write stuff

a=x;

public boolean mouseDrag(Event e,int x, int y)

draw.drawLine(a,b,x,y);

item.title: My second Java
item.dc:creator: @Galook Galook
item.description:
@Galook wrote:

[quote=“1337h4x, post:5, topic:3835”]I love for loops, much more then while loops.

for(int i = 0; i < str.length(); i++)
{
    System.out.println(str[i]);
}

Should work.[/quote]

wont work… str[i] should be str.charAt(i) :o

this would work too:

char[] characters = str.toCharArray();
for(char c : characters)
{
    System.out.println(c);
}

item.dc:creator: @koffe koffe
item.description:
@koffe wrote:

Well, here is another of my use less Java:P
i have advanced just i bit but still i am big noob
plz send feedback and help how to make it better Thx:D

public class java1 {

	public static void write(String str) {
System.out.println(str);
int var1 =str.length();
int i = 0;

while(i < var1) {
	
	System.out.println(i+"= "+str.charAt(i));
	
	i++;
	
}
	}
	public static void main(String[] args) {
write("My java");
	}

}
